fields.value: ABC News Supreme Court Nomination Poll, July 1991

dsDescriptionValue.value:
This survey focuses on the nomination of Clarence Thomas to   the Supreme Court of the United States. Respondents were asked if   they approved of the way the Supreme Court was doing its job,
if the   Supreme Court was becoming more conservative in its decisions, if   they approved of Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court, if the   Senate should only consider Thomas's background and qualifications or   if it should consider his political views as well, and if Thomas   should be confirmed only if he indicates that he would vote to   overturn/uphold the Supreme Court's 1973 ruling that allowed a woman   to have a legal abortion for any reason during the first three months   of pregnancy. Respondents also were questioned about White House   Chief of Staff John Sununu's use of government and corporate planes   while he was not on official White House business. Background   information on respondents includes political alignment, education,  age, race, sex, and state/region of residence.

topicClassValue.value: ICPSR XIV.C.1. Mass Political Behavior and Attitudes, Public Opinion on Political Matters, United States

value: Adults aged 18 and over living in households with   telephones in the 48 contiguous United States and the District of  Columbia.

fields.value: Households were selected by random digit dialing. Within   household, the respondent selected was the adult living in the   household who last had a birthday and who was at home at the time of  the interview.
